{{Use mdy dates|date=June 2012}} {{Infobox song | name = Last Friday Night (T.G.I.F.) | cover = Last Friday Night cover.png | alt = | type = single | artist = [[Katy Perry]] | album = [[Teenage Dream (Katy Perry album)|Teenage Dream]] | released = {{Start date|2011|6|6}} | format = {{hlist|[[CD single]]|[[Music download|digital download]]}} | recorded = | studio = [[Conway Recording Studios]] and eightysevenfourteen studios, (Los Angeles, California);
Playback Recording Studios
([[Santa Barbara, California]]) | venue = | genre = [[Dance-pop]] | length = 3:50 (Album version)
3:58 (Remix featuring [[Missy Elliott]]) | label = [[Capitol Records|Capitol]] | writer = {{flat list| *[[Katy Perry]] *[[Dr. Luke|Lukasz Gottwald]] *[[Max Martin]] *[[Bonnie McKee]] }} | producer = {{flat list| *Dr. Luke *Max Martin }} | prev_title = [[E.T. (song)|E.T.]] | prev_year = 2011 | next_title = [[The One That Got Away (Katy Perry song)|The One That Got Away]] | next_year = 2011 | misc = {{External music video|{{YouTube|KlyXNRrsk4A|"Last Friday Night (T.G.I.F.)"}} }} }} "'''Last Friday Night (T.G.I.F.)'''" is a song by American singer [[Katy Perry]] from her third studio album, ''[[Teenage Dream (Katy Perry album)|Teenage Dream]]''. The song was written and produced by [[Dr. Luke]] and [[Max Martin]], who also co-wrote the song with Perry and [[Bonnie McKee]]. Perry stated that she was inspired to write the track after a night of wild partying and streaking. It was released as the album's fifth single on June 6, 2011, by [[Capitol Records]], with a remix featuring American rapper [[Missy Elliott]] released to US radio stations and digital retailers on August 8, 2011; this version was included in ''[[Teenage Dream: The Complete Confection]]'' edition. It is a [[dance-pop]] song with lyrics about drunken fun and debauchery. Some of the risque lyrics in the song are often censored in radio versions of the song. The song had chart success worldwide, reaching number one in Slovakia and the Czech Republic, and has attained top-ten positions in Austria, Ireland, Italy, and Poland. By topping the US [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]], Perry became the first female solo artist to have five number-one singles on the Hot 100 from a single album; it also was Perry's sixth number-one single on the ''Billboard'' Hot 100 chart, and her fifth consecutive number one single. The single had sold 3.7 million digital copies in the US and was the tenth most played single on US radio during 2011. The song's accompanying music video was directed by [[Marc Klasfeld]]. The clip features Perry, as her teenage alter-ego Kathy Beth Terry, at a house party filled with music and dancing. While at the party, Terry is made over by her friend and draws attention to herself as the life of the party. The video features appearances by notable music artists and actors, which includes [[Rebecca Black]], [[Corey Feldman]], [[Debbie Gibson]], [[Kenny G]], [[Hanson (band)|Hanson]], and [[Kevin McHale (actor)|Kevin McHale]] and [[Darren Criss]] of ''[[Glee (TV series)|Glee]]''. According to the director, the inspiration behind the video was ''[[Sixteen Candles]]'', works by American filmmaker [[John Hughes (filmmaker)|John Hughes]], and other 1980s high school films. The music video won Favorite Music Video award at the [[38th People's Choice Awards]]. ==Background and artwork== Perry has revealed that she was inspired to write the track after running naked through a park with her friends. According to Music Rooms, Perry claims that after a wild night of partying and streaking, she wrote the song about her antics and what she remembered the next day. Perry revealed: "There's nothing better than an impromptu dance party with my friends. My track 'Last Friday Night (T.G.I.F.)' is a song about debauchery because I had one of those nights in [[Santa Barbara, California|Santa Barbara]]. We went out to this place called Wildcat and got crazy," Perry admitted: "We had a couple of beers and danced until we died, then brought the party back to the hotel room." She added: "Most of that song is actual truth, apart from the [[ménage à trois]]..... unfortunately! But, yes, streaking in the park, that's what we did, so we had to write a song about it the next day!"{{cite web |url=http://www.mtv.co.uk/artists/katy-perry/news/261855-katy-perry-streaking-naked-russell-brand |title=Katy Perry Says Streaking Inspired Album Track |date=March 10, 2011 |publisher=MTV |accessdate=June 17, 2011}} One of the friends in this trip was co-writer [[Bonnie McKee]], who said the song encapsulated "Katy and my wild drinking days" from their younger days.{{cite web|last=Diehl|first=Matt|title=Singles Lady: Bonnie McKee Is Looking Out For Number One|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/pop-shop/5646340/singles-lady-bonnie-mckee-is-looking-out-for-number-one?page=0%2C1|publisher=Billboard|accessdate=19 December 2013}} McKee stated "TGIF is pretty much a word for word description of our trip to Santa Barbara, so I love that one. It's really catchy and fun and makes me nostalgic."[http://alexkazemi.com/2010/07/listensingle-review-teenage-dream-katy-perry/ Alexkazemi.com] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100807001855/http://alexkazemi.com/2010/07/listensingle-review-teenage-dream-katy-perry/ |date=August 7, 2010 }} The official artwork for "Last Friday Night (T.G.I.F.)" using scenes from the music video, shows Perry both before and after a makeover. She revealed the cover artwork for "Last Friday Night (T.G.I.F.) Remixes!" on her Facebook page. The photo features Perry in nerdy gear, including mouth guard and glasses, and was taken when she hosted the Teen Choice Awards in summer 2010. The image is surrounded by 1980s-style neon colors and swirly graphics.{{cite web|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1663239/katy-perry-last-friday-night-single.jhtml|title=Katy Perry To Release 'Last Friday Night' As Next Single|publisher=MTV|last=Vena|first=Jocelyn|date=May 4, 2011}} A remixed version of "Last Friday Night (T.G.I.F.)", featuring [[Missy Elliott]], was released on August 8, 2011 to radio and as a digital download.{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/468097/katy-perry-could-tie-no-1s-record-with-missy-elliott-friday-remix|title=Katy Perry Could Tie No. 1s Record With Missy Elliott 'Friday' Remix|work=Billboard|last=Caulfield|first=Keith|date=August 5, 2011}} It was released as the album's fifth single on June 6, 2011 through [[Capitol Records]].{{cite web |url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/music/thesound/a316170/playlist-10-tracks-you-need-to-hear.html |title=Playlist: 10 tracks you need to hear |date=April 25, 2011 |last=Copsey |first=Robert |work=Digital Spy |accessdate=June 17, 2011}} ==Composition== {{Listen |filename = Katy Perry Last Friday Night (T.G.I.F.).ogg |pos = right |title="Last Friday Night (T.G.I.F.)" |description = A 20 second sample of "Last Friday Night (T.G.I.F.)", which features the first verse and chorus. }} "Last Friday Night (T.G.I.F.)" is a [[dance-pop]] song,{{cite journal|first= Luke |last= Larsen |title= 9 Reasons Why This Is The Year Of The Saxophone |date= 26 August 2011 |magazine= [[Paste (magazine)|Paste]] |url= http://www.pastemagazine.com/blogs/lists/2011/08/9-reasons-why-this-is-the-year-of-the-saxophone.html |accessdate= 17 June 2015}} which runs for three minutes and 50 seconds.{{cite web|url=http://www.musicnotes.com/sheetmusic/mtdVPE.asp?ppn=MN0088648|title=Katy Perry – Last Friday Night Sheet Music (Digital Download)}} It is set in [[common time]] and has a moderate tempo of 126 [[beats per minute]]. It is written in the key of [[Eb minor]], and Perry's vocals span one octave, from C♯4 to F♯5.{{cite web|title=Digital sheet music – Katy Perry – Last Friday Night (T.G.I.F.)|accessdate=May 6, 2011|publisher=Musicnotes.com}} It follows the [[chord progression]] B–G♯m7–D♯m–C♯. ==Critical reception== [[AllMusic]] picked it among the top tracks on the album, and said that Perry "salutes fellow attention-whore [[Kesha]] on 'Last Friday Night (T.G.I.F.)'".{{cite web|last=Thomas |first=Stephen |url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/teenage-dream-r1834720/review |title=Teenage Dream – Katy Perry |publisher=AllMusic |date=August 24, 2010 |accessdate=April 9, 2011}} ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' said that "Perry likes her songs chatty; in the kegger romp "Last Friday Night," she chirps, "Think I need a ginger ale/That was such an epic fail".{{cite web|last=Sheffield|first=Rob|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/albumreviews/teenage-dream-20100823 |title=Teenage Dream by Katy Perry | Music Reviews |work=Rolling Stone |date=August 23, 2010 |accessdate=April 9, 2011}} ''[[Slant Magazine]]'' said that "'Last Friday Night (T.G.I.F.)' is a lifeless roller-rink jam with a 'T! G! I! F!' shout-along that will no doubt provide the soundtrack to any number of trashy sorority parties this semester".{{cite web|url=http://www.slantmagazine.com/music/review/katy-perry-teenage-dream/2219 |title=Katy Perry: Teenage Dream |work=Slant Magazine |accessdate=April 9, 2011}} ''[[Spin Magazine]]'' said that "Last Friday Night recounts an evening of nonstop naughtiness – think streaking, skinny-dipping, and ménage à trois-ing."{{cite web|last=Wood |first=Mikael |url=http://www.spin.com/reviews/katy-perry-teenage-dream-capitol |title=Katy Perry, 'Teenage Dream' (Capitol) |work=Spin |accessdate=April 9, 2011}} Jason Richards from ''[[Now (newspaper)|Now]]'' wrote, "The singer recently said that the catchy 'Last Friday Night (T.G.I.F.)' is her version of '[[I Gotta Feeling]]'. With lyrics about photos ending up online after a debauched evening, it's also reminiscent of Lady Gaga singing about drunkenly losing her keys and phone on '[[Just Dance (song)|Just Dance]].' Derivative, sure, but the song strikes a perfect equilibrium between Perry's sex appeal and goofy, self-effacing charm".{{cite web|last=Richards |first=Jason |url=http://www.nowtoronto.com/music/discs.cfm?content=176438 |title=NOW Magazine // Music // Katy Perry |publisher=Nowtoronto.com |accessdate=April 9, 2011}} Marc Hawthorne from ''[[The A.V. Club]]'' said that "assuming that everything here is based on real life also means we have to accept that she's had a ménage à trois on the indie-rock-meets-American Idol cut Last Friday Night (T.G.I.F.)".{{cite web|last=Hawthorne |first=Marc |url=http://www.avclub.com/articles/katy-perry-teenage-dream,44690/ |title=Katy Perry: Teenage Dream |publisher=The A.V. Club |date=August 31, 2010 |accessdate=April 9, 2011}} Chris Richards from ''[[The Washington Post]]'' said that "Over strummy guitars and zigzagging keyboards, Perry recounts an evening of debauchery with no repercussions, her innocent transgressions (streaking, skinny-dipping) mentioned in the same breath as more serious trouble (mysterious bruises, a blackout), but..... [when] it's time for Perry to reflect on her 3 am follies, she stiffly sings, "That was such an epic fail." It sounds like a clueless parent's attempt to speak teenager."{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2010/08/23/AR2010082304256.html |title=Album review of 'Teenage Dream' by Katy Perry |work=The Washington Post |date= August 24, 2010|accessdate=April 9, 2011 |first=Chris |last=Richards}} ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' included the song in their ''Five Potential Pop Hits for 2011'' list.{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/chart-beat/473732/ask-billboard-readers-2010-top-picks-continued |title=Ask Billboard: Readers' 2010 Top Picks, Continued – Chart Beat |work=Billboard |accessdate=April 9, 2011}} Tom Hawthorne from ''Future Music Charts'' said that it sounds like a pop song as it should be without any auto-tune voice changes and hard DJ beats, which is the song's strength and weakness at the same time".{{cite web|last=Hawthorne |first=Tom |url=http://www.futuremusiccharts.nl/futuremusiccharts/2011/04/katy-perry-last-friday-night-tgif.html |title=Katy Perry: Teenage Dream FMC Review|publisher=Future Music Charts |date=April 20, 2011 |accessdate=August 20, 2011}} In the form of an [[open letter]] to Perry, comedian [[Rob Delaney (comedian)|Rob Delaney]] takes her to task for glamorizing [[binge drinking]], [[unsafe sex]], and possibly [[date rape]] in the song. He comments on it lyric-by-lyric, sometimes humorously (in response to the line "''Yeah we maxed our credit cards''", Delaney writes "[[Suze Orman]] would be so angry if I told her this.") but more often seriously. To the line "''Don't know what to tell my boss''", he says: {{quote|Why do you have to tell your boss anything? Were your exploits reported in the paper? Is your boss also your landlord? Wait—aren't you international pop superstar, Katy Perry? I would have thought you were your own boss. Uh oh, I think we're arriving at why this song is not just awful, but is in fact dangerous. You are playing a character in this song! A character ''based on the young female demographic you target your music at'': young women who do have jobs and bosses and mothers and fathers and necks and vaginas which sure as hell will be damaged and violated if they subscribe to the ideas you foist on them with your songs and the confusing "goofy slut" persona you've created.{{Cite web|last=Delaney|first=Rob|authorlink=Rob Delaney (comedian)|title=Dear Katy Perry|url=https://www.vice.com/read/take-a-stroll-with-rob-delaney-dear-katy-perry|work=[[Vice (magazine)|vice.com]]|date=October 2011|accessdate=July 9, 2012}}}} ==Chart performance== [[File:Katy Perry 2011 3.jpg|thumb|150px|left|Perry performing the song on her ''[[California Dreams Tour]]'']] "Last Friday Night (T.G.I.F.)" made Perry the first and only female artist to have five #1 singles from one album in ''Billboard'' Hot 100, tying [[Michael Jackson]]'s ''[[Bad (album)|Bad]]'', with his last #1 single being "[[Dirty Diana]]", on July 2, 1988. Perry's song debuted at number 67 on the ''Billboard'' Hot 100.{{cite web|author=Pietroluongo, Silvio (September 2, 2010).|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/956542/eminem-and-rihanna-still-no-1-on-hot-100-cee-los-fk-you-debuts |title=Eminem and Rihanna Still No. 1 on Hot 100, Cee Lo's 'F**k You' Debuts |work=Billboard |accessdate=April 9, 2011}} It also charted at number 49 on the [[Canadian Hot 100]] chart that same week. Following its single release, the song re-entered the ''Billboard'' Hot 100 on June 18, 2011 at number 63 and at number 31 on the ''Billboard'' [[Pop Songs]].{{cite web|author=Trust, Gary (June 8, 2011).|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/470794/adeles-still-deep-atop-hot-100-coldplay-makes-a-splash |title=Adele's Still 'Deep' Atop Hot 100, Coldplay Makes a Splash |work=Billboard |accessdate=June 8, 2011}} The following week, the song jumped 63-31 with the Hot 100's "Greatest Gainer" award.{{cite web|author=Trust, Gary (June 15, 2011).|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/470537/adele-rolling-along-atop-hot-100-jason-aldean-nicki-minaj-reach-top-10 |title=Adele 'Rolling' Along Atop Hot 100, Jason Aldean & Nicki Minaj Reach Top 10 |work=Billboard |accessdate=June 15, 2011}} In its fourth week on the chart, "Friday" leaped to number four, spurred by a number one ranking on [[Hot Digital Songs]]. This made ''[[Teenage Dream (Katy Perry album)|Teenage Dream]]'' the first album to have five songs hit number one on the chart.{{cite web|author=Trust, Gary (June 22, 2011).|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/470092/katy-perrys-friday-flies-up-hot-100-adele-still-no-1 |title=Katy Perry's 'Friday' Flies Up Hot 100, Adele Still No. 1 |work=Billboard |accessdate=June 22, 2011}} The song reached number three on the ''Billboard'' Hot 100 chart, on July 30. The following week, "Last Friday Night (T.G.I.F.)", reached a new position of number two, where it remained for three additional weeks, behind "[[Party Rock Anthem]]" by [[LMFAO (group)|LMFAO]] feat. [[Lauren Bennett]] and [[GoonRock]].{{cite web|author=Trust, Gary (August 10, 2011).|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/467986/lmfao-keeps-katy-perry-at-bay-atop-hot-100 |title= 'LMFAO Keeps Katy Perry At Bay Atop Hot 100'. |publisher=Billboard (Nielsen Business Media, Inc). |date=August 10, 2011 |accessdate=August 10, 2011}} The song finally reached the number-one position on the ''Billboard'' Hot 100 on August 17, 2011, and spent two straight weeks there. The song became Perry's sixth number-one single on the ''Billboard'' Hot 100 chart, and her fifth consecutive number-one single. Perry became the first woman in the 53-year history of ''Billboard'' to take five singles from the same album to number one on the ''Billboard'' Hot 100, equaling the record established by Michael Jackson 23 years earlier.{{cite web|last=Trust|first=Gary|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/467879/katy-perry-makes-hot-100-history-ties-michael-jacksons-record |title= Katy Perry Makes Hot 100 History: Ties Michael Jackson's Record|work=Billboard|date= August 17, 2011 |accessdate=August 17, 2011}} The song has also peaked at number-one on the Canadian Hot 100, and has become her fourth number-one single from the album. As of January 2015, the single had sold 3.7 million copies in the US.{{cite web |url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/chart-beat/6450846/ask-billboard-controversial-hits-katy-perrys-sales-taylor-swifts?page=0%2C1 |title=Ask Billboard: Controversial Hits, Katy Perry's Sales & Taylor Swift's Radio Reign |last=Trust |first=Gary |work=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |date=January 25, 2015 |accessdate=January 25, 2015}} According to [[Nielsen Broadcast Data Systems]], "Last Friday Night (T.G.I.F)" was the tenth most played single on US radio during 2011 with 450,000 plays.{{cite web|title=The Nielsen Company & Billboard's 2011 Music Industry Report|url=http://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20120105005547/en/Nielsen-Company-Billboard%E2%80%99s-2011-Music-Industry-Report|accessdate=January 5, 2012}} "Last Friday Night (T.G.I.F.)" peaked at number two on the [[Irish Singles Chart]]. On the [[New Zealand Singles Chart]] it peaked at number four, marking Perry's first top spot miss, though it still managed to receive platinum by the [[Recording Industry Association of New Zealand]], making it her fifth platinum selling single from her album. The song debuted at number 40 in Australia, and later peaked at number five in the country and going platinum. In the UK, the song peaked at No. 9 in the UK Singles Chart. September 17, 2011 marked Perry' 69th consecutive week in the Top 10 with the single.{{Cite news|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/467566/adeles-someone-like-you-soars-to-no-1-on-hot-100|work=Billboard|title=Adele's 'Someone Like You' Soars To No. 1 On Hot 100|first=Gary|last=Trust|date=September 7, 2011|accessdate=September 7, 2011}} ==Music video== ===Background and release=== {{double image|right|Kevin McHale by Gage Skidmore.jpg|170|DCriss.jpg|140|[[Kevin McHale (actor)|Kevin McHale]] ''(left)'' and [[Darren Criss]] ''(right)'' from the TV series ''[[Glee (TV series)|Glee]]'', among other celebrities, star in the music video.}} In an interview with MTV, director [[Marc Klasfeld]] said that the video's storyline was inspired by ''[[Sixteen Candles]]'' and other works of [[John Hughes (filmmaker)|John Hughes]], as well as "all those great '80s high school movies."{{cite web |url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1666061/katy-perry-last-friday-night-video.jhtml |title=Katy Perry's 'Last Friday Night' Video: Frame By Frame |date=June 20, 2011 |last=Vena |first=Jocelyn |publisher=[[MTV]] |accessdate=June 22, 2011}} Including a long series of outtakes during the ending credits was influenced by a similar idea in ''[[The Cannonball Run (film)|The Cannonball Run]]''. The costume for Perry's character, Kathy Beth Terry, was inspired by the character [[Betty Suarez]], played by [[America Ferrera]] on the series ''[[Ugly Betty]]''. The music video for "Last Friday Night (T.G.I.F.)" was filmed around May 3–6, 2011 at the home of [[John Schneider (screen actor)|John Schneider]]. It was directed by [[Marc Klasfeld]], and co-directed by Danny Lockwood.{{cite web|url=http://www.videostatic.com/vs/2011/06/in-production-katy-perry-marc-klasfeld-dir.html|publisher=Videostatic.com|title=IN PRODUCTION: Katy Perry – Marc Klasfeld, dir.|date=June 10, 2011|last=Gottlieb|first=Steven}} Perry tweeted, "I told someone about my new music video I just filmed & they responded with 'wow, that's gonna break the internet.'..... Should I knock on wood?" Before the video premiered, Perry created Facebook and Twitter profiles for a "brace-faced nerd-turned-hottie" thirteen-year-old she plays named Kathy Beth Terry.{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/viral-videos/470581/katy-perry-parties-with-rebecca-black-glee-cast-in-last-friday |title=Katy Perry Parties With Rebecca Black, 'Glee' Cast in 'Last Friday Night' Video |date=June 13, 2011 |last=Mapes |first=Jillian |work=Billboard|accessdate=June 22, 2011}} Starting from June 8, a series of short video clips was uploaded on the Facebook profile, YouTube and Perry's official web version premiered later on the same day on [[Funny or Die]]. On July 11, after crossing the half-million "likes" mark, Perry released an interview in character as Terry on DigitalSpy.{{cite web|author=Jul 11, 2011, 12:02 BST|url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/music/interviews/a328976/kathy-beth-terry-interview-katy-perry-has-been-great-to-me.html |title=Kathy Beth Terry interview: "Katy Perry has been great to me" – Music Interview |work=Digital Spy |date=July 11, 2011 |accessdate=January 22, 2012}} Perry, in character as Kathy Beth Terry made various references to [[Rebecca Black]] and other guests on the video on her Twitter and Facebook. She also gave interviews to the Digitalspy, Australian [[Cosmopolitan (magazine)|Cosmopolitan]], and BOP Tiger Beat.{{cite web|url=http://www.cosmopolitan.com.au/cosmo_chats_kathy_beth_terry.htm# |title=Cosmo chats: Kathy Beth Terry |publisher=Cosmopolitan|date=July 18, 2011 |accessdate=January 22, 2012}}[http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/music/interviews/a328976/kathy-beth-terry-interview-katy-perry-hast 5, 2011] The video went on to win Favorite Music Video award at the [[38th People's Choice Awards]].{{cite web|title=And The Nominees Are.....|url=http://www.peopleschoice.com/pca/awards/nominees/|publisher=PeoplesChoice.com|accessdate=January 12, 2012}} As of October 2018, the video has over 1.1 billion views on [[YouTube]].{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KlyXNRrsk4A|title=Katy Perry – Last Friday Night|publisher=[[YouTube]]|accessdate=March 27, 2017}} ===Synopsis=== [[File:LFN KatyPerry video.jpg|thumb|left|220px|Perry's alter-ego 'Kathy Beth Terry' in the music video for "Last Friday Night (T.G.I.F.)"]] Kathy Beth Terry (Perry), a nerdy teenager with braces, headgear, and oversized glasses, has just awakened the morning after a house party, surrounded by passed-out partygoers. A male guest, Aaron Christopherson (''[[Glee (TV series)|Glee]]'' star [[Darren Criss]]) opens the door to her bedroom and congratulates her on having the "best party ever." Puzzled as to what happened, she goes online, only to find pictures of herself in various compromising positions, including one picture of her licking the stomach of the boy in bed next to her. The video then goes into a flashback of the events that occurred the night before. While doing a [[Sudoku]] puzzle, Kathy hears loud music from the house next door, and goes over to complain. She is greeted by [[Rebecca Black]] (who appears as a homage to Black's viral video "[[Friday (Rebecca Black song)|Friday]]"), who invites her in. A nerdy Everett McDonald (''[[Glee (TV series)|Glee]]'' star [[Kevin McHale (actor)|Kevin McHale]]) ogles Terry from afar and fantasizes about being with her. However, Kathy is more interested in Steve Johnson aka "The [[Jock (athlete)|Jock]]" (model Richie Nuzzolese), an attractive football player, who turns her down because of her appearance. To cheer her up, Black gives Kathy a makeover, ripping off her headgear with pliers, waxing her upper lip, dressing her in tight-fitting neon clothes, and teasing her hair out. Steve becomes enamored with her, and everyone starts dancing. Kathy and Rebecca are also seen playing the song "[[Hot Stuff (Donna Summer song)|Hot Stuff]]" on ''[[Just Dance 2]]'' by [[Ubisoft]] (a game that features Perry as DLC). Musician [[Kenny G]], despite not having played the saxophone on the song's actual recording, plays the saxophone solo on the roof while [[Hanson (band)|Hanson]] act as the house band. The entire party ends up moving to Kathy's house, where she throws up after drinking too much. Everett punches Steve for trying to fondle Kathy's buttocks (visualized by him as a medieval sword fight with Kathy as a [[damsel in distress]]). At the end of the night, Kathy finally passes out next to Steve. The video shifts back to the next morning, where she looks at the photos with regret, but is also ecstatic to have a naked Steve passed out in her bed. The film ends with former [[teen idol]]s [[Corey Feldman]] and [[Debbie Gibson]] as Kathy's parents, Kirk and Tiffany Terry, confronting Kathy about the state of the house but forgiving her after recalling their own wild youth, Feldman making several references to ''[[The Lost Boys]]'', in which he starred. The video's ending credits feature various deleted lines, bloopers, and extra scenes from the party, as well as Everett bringing Kathy breakfast in bed. After the credits end, it repeats the shot where Kathy gets tape ripped off her upper lip; her scream is heard this time. ==Live performances== On September 5, 2010, Perry performed the song live for the first time along with "[[Teenage Dream (Katy Perry song)|Teenage Dream]]", "[[Firework (song)|Firework]]" and "[[Not Like The Movies]]" in the show's launch of the ''Teenage Dream'' in Berlin. Though the song has never been performed live as part of a televised performance, the song is featured on the set lists of the ''Teenage Dream Tour'', ''[[California Dreams Tour]]'', ''[[Prismatic World Tour]]'' and ''[[Witness: The Tour]]''. The first televised performance was during her presentation at [[Rock In Rio]], which was broadcast live by the [[Multishow]]. During this song, photos of fans are displayed on the screens.{{cite web |url=http://music.einnews.com/pr-news/385792-katy-perry-debuts-tweet-to-screen-for-california-dreams-2011-tour- |title=Katy Perry Debuts Tweet-to-Screen for California Dreams 2011 Tour – Music Industry Today |publisher=Music.einnews.com |accessdate=November 11, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110724051624/http://music.einnews.com/pr-news/385792-katy-perry-debuts-tweet-to-screen-for-california-dreams-2011-tour- |archivedate=July 24, 2011 |df=mdy-all }} ==Formats and track listings== * '''Promotional CD single'''{{cite web|author=Steffen Hung |url=http://uk-charts.com/showitem.asp?interpret=Katy+Perry&titel=Last+Friday+Night+(T.G.I.F.)&cat=s |title=Katy Perry – Last Friday Night (T.G.I.F.) |publisher=uk-charts.com |accessdate=January 22, 2012}} # "Last Friday Night (T.G.I.F.) {{italic title|string=Maclean's}} '''''Maclean's'' "Too Asian" controversy''' is a controversy around an article published by ''[[Maclean's]]'' in 2010. Initially titled "Too Asian: Some frosh don't want to study at an Asian university", later re-titled with an added question mark "Too Asian? [...]", and then finally "The enrollment controversy: Worries that efforts in the U.S. to limit enrollment of Asian students in top universities may migrate to Canada,"<ref>{{cite web |last=Smith |first=Charlie |url=https://www.straight.com/article-361819/vancouver/macleans-changes-title-too-asian-article-enrollment-controvery |title=Macleans changes the title of "Too Asian?" article to "The enrollment controversy" |publisher=Straight.com |date=2010-11-29 |accessdate=2012-04-04}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.uglychinesecanadian.com/?p=3126 |title=Newsmagazine explores Canadian universities as being "too Asian" |publisher=Uglychinesecanadian.com |date= |accessdate=2012-04-04}}</ref> this article was written by Nicholas Kohler and Stephanie Findlay, and published in the 2010 edition of the ''[[Maclean's]] Guide to Canadian Universities''.<ref name="macleans1">{{cite web |url=http://oncampus.macleans.ca/education/2010/11/10/too-asian/ |title=The enrollment controversy |publisher=Macleans OnCampus |date=2010-11-10 |accessdate=2012-04-04}}</ref> The article was publicly criticized and condemned by various community organizations,<ref name="Open Letter">{{cite web |url=http://asiancanadianstudies.ca/node/31 |title=Open Letter - A Call to Eliminate Anti-Asian Racism |publisher=Asian Canadian Studies |date= |accessdate=2012-04-04}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.philippinereporter.com/2011/01/28/%E2%80%98too-asian%E2%80%99-too-racist/ |title=‘Too Asian,’ too racist |newspaper=[[Philippine Reporter]] |date=2011-01-28 |accessdate=2012-04-04 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120608142821/http://www.philippinereporter.com/2011/01/28/%E2%80%98too-asian%E2%80%99-too-racist/ |archivedate=2012-06-08 |df= }}</ref> universities<ref>{{cite web |last=Alphonsus |first=Jonathan |url=http://www.trentarthur.ca/index.php/nation/2194-qtoo-asianq-macleans-how-about-too-racist |title="Too asian," Maclean's? How about too racist |publisher=Trentarthur.ca |date=2010-12-01 |accessdate=2012-04-04 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120420204037/http://www.trentarthur.ca/index.php/nation/2194-qtoo-asianq-macleans-how-about-too-racist |archivedate=2012-04-20 |df= }}</ref><ref>[http://thevarsity.ca/articles/38372 38372]{{dead link|date=April 2012}}</ref> and levels of [[Government of Canada|government]] as an example of anti-[[Asian people|Asian]] [[racism]] and [[xenophobia]].<ref name="oliviachow1">{{cite web |url=http://www.oliviachow.ca/2010/12/olivia-chows-motion-re-too-asian-article/ |title=Blog Archive » Olivia Chow introduces motion condemning "Too Asian?" article |publisher=Olivia Chow, MP |date=2010-12-03 |accessdate=2012-04-04 |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130115130130/http://www.oliviachow.ca/2010/12/olivia-chows-motion-re-too-asian-article/# |archive-date=2013-01-15 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> To date, ''Maclean's'' magazine and its parent company, [[Rogers Communications]], have declined to offer an apology for the article.
==Article's content and criticism== The article begins by introducing Alexandra and Rachel, two recently graduated [[White people|white]] students from [[Havergal College]], an [[elite]] [[Single-sex education|all-girl]]'s [[private school]] located in [[Toronto]]. Kohler and Findlay explain that these students made a choice that is common among [[North America]]'s white youth: opting not to attend a [[university]] with the reputation of being "too Asian". The term, Kohler and Findlay continue to explain, indicates a university that is intellectually rigorous with an unbalanced [[campus]] social climate, brought upon by the presence of academically focused Asian students.<ref name="macleans1" /> The article concludes with a note that Alexandra left [[University of Western Ontario|Western University]], a school considered to be attended by "white students" in the article, for [[University of Toronto]], which is considered to be "too Asian".
Many critics argued that the article's subsequent attempts to provide a debate about the role of race on [[List of universities in Canada|Canadian university campuses]], and the "over-representation" of Asian students on elite university campuses, was highly offensive: it framed "Asian" students as single-minded and socially inept hard-workers, spurred by their tradition and culture, while "white" students are more concerned with the social aspect of universities, such as drinking and partying. Many critiques also took issue with the article's conflation of "[[Asian people|Asian]]" with [[Chinese people|Chinese]], quoting a number of Chinese students in their article, while never addressing how "Asian" itself is a category that subsumes many different ethnic groups. Moreover, no distinction between international students and Canadian-born "Asians" was made (an important distinction that was completely disregarded in the survey). Critics were also shocked by the article's reference to debates in American universities regarding the initiation of race-based quotas to "balance" their campuses because of the over-representation of Asian students.<ref name="macleans1" />
Response to the article was immediate, widespread and disfavourable.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://fullcomment.nationalpost.com/2010/11/15/jeet-heer-macleans-article-on-asians-familiar-to-anti-semites-of-old/ |first=Jeet|last=Heer |title=Maclean’s article on Asians familiar to anti-Semites of old |newspaper=[[National Post]] |date=2010-11-15 |accessdate=2012-04-04}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |first=Zi-Ann |last=Lum |url=http://www.vancouverobserver.com/blogs/divercity/2010/11/11/too-asian-too-racist-magazine-macleans |title="Too Asian?" too racist for a magazine like Maclean's? |newspaper=The Vancouver Observer |date=2010-11-11 |accessdate=2012-04-04}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://jezebel.com/5687559/yes-calling-a-school-too-asian-is-racist |title=Yes, Calling A School "Too Asian" Is Racist |publisher=Jezebel.com |date=2010-11-11 |accessdate=2012-04-04}}</ref> Critics{{snd}} ranging from journalist bloggers<ref name="tumblr1">{{cite web |url=http://etiquette-etc.tumblr.com/post/1607948924/not-white-enough-what-the-macleans-article-says-about |title=Etiquette, etc |publisher=Etiquette-etc.tumblr.com |date=2010-11-17 |accessdate=2012-04-04 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120425231218/http://etiquette-etc.tumblr.com/post/1607948924/not-white-enough-what-the-macleans-article-says-about |archivedate=2012-04-25 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |author=Ask a Model Minority Suicide |url=http://www.hyphenmagazine.com/blog/archive/2010/11/too-asian-responding-question |title='Too Asian?': Responding to the Question |publisher=Hyphen magazine |date=2010-11-15 |accessdate=2012-04-04}}</ref><ref name="racialicious1">{{cite web |first=Arturo R. |last=García |url=http://www.racialicious.com/2010/11/12/macleans-magazine-revisits-old-fears-with-too-asian-article/ |title=Maclean’s Magazine revisits old fears with ‘Too Asian?’ article |publisher=Racialicious |date=2010-11-12 |accessdate=2012-04-04 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120608095453/http://www.racialicious.com/2010/11/12/macleans-magazine-revisits-old-fears-with-too-asian-article/ |archivedate=2012-06-08 |df= }}</ref> to academics<ref>{{cite news |first=Krissy |last=Darch |url=http://www.vancouverobserver.com/blogs/thescene/2010/11/25/asian-whatever-means |title=Asian, whatever that means |newspaper=The Vancouver Observer |date=2010-11-25 |accessdate=2012-04-04}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.straight.com/article-358546/vancouver/henry-yu-why-macleans-and-racism-should-no-longer-define-canada |first=Henry |last=Yu |title=Why Macleans and racism should no longer define Canada |publisher=Straight.com |date=2010-11-16 |accessdate=2012-04-04}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://ring.uvic.ca/10dec/tooasian.html |first=Shelly |last=Chan |title="Too Asian"? We must defend diversity at all costs |publisher=The Ring |date=2010-12-03 |accessdate=2012-04-04}}</ref>{{snd}} decried the article for being racist, [[Stereotype|stereotypical]] and reductive. The article was criticized for recalling stereotypes of Asians as unbalanced foreigners, with the aim of overthrowing white [[Canadians]] from power.<ref name="Open Letter" /><ref name="theglobeandmail1">{{cite news |first=Minelle |last=Mahtani |url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/commentary/canadian-media-its-time-to-cover-the-undercovered/article1314521/ |title=Canadian media: It’s time to cover the undercovered |newspaper=The Globe and Mail |date=2010-11-19 |accessdate=2012-04-04 |location=Toronto}}</ref>
Further criticism followed from the fact that the article depicted Asians as a homogeneous group, without attention to the fact that people from various groups can be classified as "Asian".<ref name="walrusmagazine1">{{cite web |url=http://www.walrusmagazine.com/blogs/2010/11/24/too-brazen/ |title=Too Brazen |first=Jeet |last=Heer |publisher=The Walrus Blog |date=2010-11-24 |accessdate=2012-04-04 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121202222425/http://walrusmagazine.com/blogs/2010/11/24/too-brazen/ |archive-date=2012-12-02 |dead-url=yes}}</ref> Another commentator argued that the article inaccurately perpetuated the myth that universities functioned as [[Meritocracy|meritocracies]], without taking into account that minorities have to overcome social hurdles, such as racial discrimination and [[prejudice]].<ref>{{cite web |last=Ghabrial |first=Sarah |url=http://rabble.ca/news/2010/11/when-asians-enroll-and-other-tales-meritocracy%E2%80%99s-margins |title=When Asians enroll! (And other tales from meritocracy's margins) |publisher=Rabble.ca |date=2010-11-17 |accessdate=2012-04-04}}</ref> It was also argued that the article justified the idea that whites are entitled to attend university, because it never explicitly condemns, and therefore indirectly condones, Alexandra and Rachel's belief that certain universities were "too Asian".<ref name="tumblr1" />
==Protest and government action== Coupled with the critiques of the piece was activism and action from [[grassroots]], academic, governmental, university, and youth sectors. The activism protesting the piece manifested in a number of different forms, ranging from humorous (but critical) videos,<ref>{{cite news |first=Tetsuro |last=Shigematsu |url=http://www.vancouverobserver.com/blogs/thescene/2011/01/25/too-asian |title=Too Asian? |newspaper=The Vancouver Observer |date=2011-01-25 |accessdate=2012-04-04}}</ref> to community web pages<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.facebook.com/TooAsianTALKBACK |title="Too Asian"? TALK BACK |publisher=Facebook |date= |accessdate=2012-04-04}}</ref> and gatherings. A coalition of over one hundred organizations composed and submitted an open letter calling for an end to anti-Asian racism for those responsible for the piece.<ref name="Open Letter" /> Universities across the nation held a series of public educational events, organized by both faculty and students, to debate the article and its implications.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.journalism.ubc.ca/news/item/ubc_forum_tackles_macleans_too_asian_article |title=UBC forum tackles Maclean’s ‘Too Asian?’ article |publisher=UBC Graduate School of Journalism |date= |accessdate=2012-04-04 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120308225119/http://www.journalism.ubc.ca/news/item/ubc_forum_tackles_macleans_too_asian_article |archivedate=2012-03-08 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url= http://web.uvic.ca/pacificasia/newsletters/NL2010.pdf |title=University of Victoria }} {{dead link|date=January 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://journalism.ryerson.ca/article/12080/ |first=Brooke |last=Wilkinson |title=Ryerson hosts 'Too Asian' event |publisher=Ryerson School of Journalism, Ryerson University |date=2011-01-28 |accessdate=2012-04-04 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120425231221/http://journalism.ryerson.ca/article/12080/ |archivedate=2012-04-25 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.uc.utoronto.ca/component/option,com_events/task,view_detail/agid,424/year,2011/month,2/day,15/Itemid,163/catids,65/ |title=Race in Media and Higher Education: A Town Hall |publisher=University College, University of Toronto |date=2011-02-15 |accessdate=2012-04-04}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.yorku.ca/rights/archive/mediaracism.htm |title=Media racism |publisher=Yorku.ca |date= |accessdate=2012-04-04}}</ref> The [[University of Victoria Students' Society]] went so far as to ban sales of the magazine from their student building.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.martlet.ca/martlet/article/uvss-plans-consumer-boycott-macleans/ |title=UVSS plans consumer boycott of Maclean’s |newspaper=The Martlet |date= |accessdate=2012-04-04 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120905174318/http://www.martlet.ca/martlet/article/uvss-plans-consumer-boycott-macleans/ |archivedate=2012-09-05 |df= }}</ref>
The cities of [[Victoria, British Columbia|Victoria]],<ref>{{cite web |url=http://asiancanadianstudies.ca/node/29 |title=City of Victoria council motion condemning Maclean's 'Too Asian' article |publisher=Asian Canadian Studies |date=2010-11-25 |accessdate=2012-04-04}}</ref> [[Vancouver]],<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.straight.com/article-364815/vancouver/vancouver-city-council-passes-motion-calling-apology-too-asian-article |first=Yolande |last=Cole |title=Vancouver city council passes motion calling for apology on Maclean’s "Too Asian?" article |publisher=Straight.com |date=2010-12-15 |accessdate=2012-04-04}}</ref> [[Toronto]],<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.straight.com/article-364900/vancouver/toronto-becomes-third-city-condemn-macleans-too-asian-article |first=Yolande |last=Cole |title=Toronto becomes third city to condemn Maclean's "Too Asian" article |publisher=Straight.com |date=2010-12-17 |accessdate=2012-04-04}}</ref> [[Markham, Ontario|Markham]],<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ccnc.ca/content/pr.php?entry=234 |title=CCNC Welcomes Markham Council Motion |publisher=Chinese Canadian National Council |date=2011-02-09 |accessdate=2012-04-04}}</ref> and [[Richmond Hill, Ontario|Richmond Hill]]<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.yorkregion.com/news-story/1429193-richmond-hill-s-too-asian-motion-praised/ |title=Richmond Hill's 'Too Asian' motion praised |work=yorkregion.com |date=2011-02-17 |accessdate=2015-01-31}}</ref> successively passed [[Motion (legal)|motion]]s condemning the article and calling for those responsible for the article to issue a public apology. [[Olivia Chow]], a [[Member of Parliament]] and member of the [[New Democratic Party of Canada|New Democratic Party]], put forth a motion in the [[House of Commons of Canada]] calling for the censure of ''Maclean's'', arguing that the article "is offensive, divisive and suggests that Canadian students of Asian heritage may be limiting opportunities for non-Asian students at certain universities".<ref name="oliviachow1" /> [[Senate of Canada|Senator]] [[Vivienne Poy]], former [[Chancellor (education)|Chancellor]] Emerita of the [[University of Toronto]], argued that the offensive content of the piece makes the magazine unsuitable as a beneficiary of the Canadian government's periodical fund{{snd}} which identifies it as "material that is denigrating to an identifiable group". The periodical fund annually subsidizes the magazine's publication with $1.8 million of federal funding.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.viviennepoy.ca/english/speeches/2010Speeches/Moore,J_161210(2).pdf |first=Vivienne |last=Poy |title=Letter to The Hon. James Moore, Minister of Canadian Heritage and Official Languages |work=viviennepoy.ca |date=2010-12-16 |accessdate=2015-01-31}}</ref>
==Maclean's response and aftermath== No apology has been offered by either ''Maclean's'' or Rogers Communications. Negotiations between Maclean's and Rogers Communications, and the [[Chinese Canadian National Council]] and the Chinese Canadian National Council Toronto Chapter were held, but those failed to yield an apology, as the magazine refused to acknowledge that the article was offensive.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ccnc.ca/content/pr.php?entry=218 |title=CCNC Statement on Dialogue with Maclean’s |publisher=Chinese Canadian National Council |date=2010-11-22 |accessdate=2012-04-04}}</ref> The magazine instead initially revised the piece's content.<ref name="racialicious1" /> It then issued a clarification about the piece's content,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.newswire.ca/en/story/665157/maclean-s-issues-clarification |title=Maclean's Issues Clarification |publisher=Newswire.ca |date=2010-11-10 |accessdate=2012-04-04}}</ref> changed the article's title twice,<ref>[https://www.straight.com/article-361819/vancouver/macleans-changes-title-too-asian-article-enrollment-controversy Maclean's changes title Too Asian article enrollment controversy]{{dead link|date=April 2012}}</ref> and issued an additional statement with the online version of the piece, stating that some of the content could be interpreted as offensive. ''Maclean's'' stated that they do not advocate race as a criterion in university admissions, and commended Asians in Canada for succeeding in universities on the basis of merit.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www2.macleans.ca/2010/11/25/who-gets-into-university/ |title=Merit: the best and only way to decide who gets into university |publisher=Maclean's Magazine |date=2010-11-25 |accessdate=2012-04-04}}</ref> Journalists [[Margaret Wente]] and [[Barbara Kay]] respectively sided with the magazine, stating that it initiated an important conversation that Canadians were afraid to have, and that the magazine, rather than those aggrieved, deserved an apology.<ref>{{cite news |first=Margaret |last=Wente |url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/commentary/where-cherished-values-collide/article4348879/ |title=Where cherished values collide |newspaper=The Globe and Mail |date=2010-11-23 |accessdate=2012-04-04 |location=Toronto}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://fullcomment.nationalpost.com/2010/11/23/barbara-kay-macleans-owed-an-apology-over-anti-asian-racism-claims/ |first=Barbara |last=Kay |title=Maclean’s owed an apology over anti-Asian racism claims |newspaper=National Post |date=2010-11-23 |accessdate=2012-04-04}}</ref>
In response, Professor Henry Yu of the [[University of British Columbia]] labelled ''Maclean's'' actions as a non-apology.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.straight.com/article-361680/vancouver/henry-yu-macleans-offers-nonapology-writing-nonstory-called-too-asian |first=Henry |last=Yu |title=Macleans offers a nonapology for writing a nonstory called "Too Asian?" |publisher=Straight.com |date=2010-11-27 |accessdate=2012-04-04}}</ref> John Miller, a former Professor of [[Journalism]] at [[Ryerson University]], argued that the article was an example of poor journalism and ''Maclean's'' reply indicated that "the publication just doesn't seem to get it."<ref>{{cite web |first=John |last=Miller |url=http://www.thejournalismdoctor.ca/Blog.php/archived/20110101/shame-on-maclean-s |title=Blog: Shame on Maclean's |publisher=The Journalism Doctor |date=2011-01-27 |accessdate=2012-04-04}}</ref> Journalist Jeet Heer articulated that, in dealing with the ordeal in the way that they did, both ''Maclean's'' and its supporters reflected Canada's inability to constructively talk about the reality of racism. Heer further noted that those who argued in favor of the article evaded acknowledging that it was evocative of racist stereotypes.<ref name="theglobeandmail1" /><ref name="walrusmagazine1" />
[[Kenneth Whyte]], then publisher of ''Maclean's'', has since been promoted as the Head of Rogers' Publications.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://j-source.ca/article/macleans-ken-whyte-promoted-head-rogers-publishing |first=Janice |last=Neil |title=Maclean's Ken Whyte promoted to head Rogers Publishing |publisher=Canadian Journalism Project |date=2011-06-17 |accessdate=2012-04-04}}</ref> Nicholas Kohler, one of the authors of the article, is no longer on staff with the magazine.{{Citation needed|date=March 2012}} Stephanie Findlay, the second author and then an intern with the publication, moved on to an internship with the ''[[Toronto Star]]''.{{Citation needed|date=March 2012}} The decision to hire Findlay by the ''Star'' was criticized by some, prompting doubt{{Citation needed|date=March 2012}} as to whether or not the ''Star'' was sincere in issuing an apology<ref>{{cite web |url= https://www.thestar.com/opinion/public_editor/2010/11/20/english_star_falls_below_its_standard.html |title=English: Star falls below its standard |first=Kathy |last=English |work=Toronto Star |date=2010-11-20 |accessdate=2015-01-31}}</ref> for a similar themed and timed article.<ref>{{cite web |last=Chatterjee |first=Soma |url=http://rabble.ca/news/2010/11/macleans-and-toronto-star-asian-invasion-higher-education |title=Maclean's and The Toronto Star: The Asian invasion of higher education |publisher=Rabble.ca |date=2010-11-24 |accessdate=2012-04-04}}</ref> Findlay is no longer with the ''Star''. Dr. Susan R. Grosbeck, the [[Principal (school)|Principal]] of [[Havergal College]], publicly stated that ''Maclean's'' never confirmed that Alexandra and Rachel actually attended the school.<ref>{{cite news |first=Susan R. |last=Groesbeck |url=http://www.vancourier.com/story_print.html?id=3945180&sponsor |title=Havergal College does not encourage racism |newspaper=Vancouver Courier |date=2010-12-08 |accessdate=2012-04-04 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120531200312/http://www.vancourier.com/story_print.html?id=3945180&sponsor |archivedate=2012-05-31 |df= }}</ref> Furthermore, a number of people interviewed by the authors expressed that they had either been misquoted,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ccnc.ca/content/pr.php?entry=228 |title=CCNC Responds to Maclean’s Statement |publisher=Chinese Canadian National Council |date=2010-12-19 |accessdate=2012-04-04}}</ref> or that the authors were dishonest in their explanation of their opinions.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.briancheung.ca/?p=241 |title=UBCCVC Response to Macleans "Too Asian?" |publisher=Brian Cheung |date=2010-12-10 |accessdate=2012-04-04}}</ref>
To commemorate the year of activism that resulted from the article's publication, an event organized by the Solidarity Committee Against Anti-Asian Racism was held at the University of Toronto on November 17, 2011.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.settlementatwork.org/_event_/93730 |title="Too Asian?" Revisited: Racism, Offensive Content, and Freedom of Speech |publisher=Settlement At Work |date=2011-11-17 |accessdate=2012-04-04 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120425231643/http://www.settlementatwork.org/_event_/93730# |archive-date=2012-04-25 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref>

The song was released as a digital download on 20 January 2018 through Low Wood and Play Two as the lead single from their second studio album ''Vu d'ici'' (2018). It [[France in the Eurovision Song Contest 2018|represented France]] in the [[Eurovision Song Contest 2018]] in [[Lisbon]], [[Portugal]]. ==Composition== "Mercy" was written and produced by [[Madame Monsieur|Émilie Satt]] and [[Madame Monsieur|Jean-Karl Lucas]]. The song is about a girl named Mercy who was born to [[Nigerian refugees]] on a boat on the [[Mediterranean Sea]] in the midst of the [[European migrant crisis]].{{cite web|url=http://wiwibloggs.com/2018/01/01/mercy-madame-monsieur-confirmed-frances-destination-eurovision/206359/|title=HAVE "MERCY"! MADAME MONSIEUR CONFIRMED FOR FRANCE’S DESTINATION EUROVISION|date=1 January 2018|last=Lee Adams|first=William|website=wiwibloggs.com}}{{cite web|url=http://www.programme-television.org/news-tv/RECAP-Destination-Eurovision-France-2-un-ancien-de-The-Voice-et-une-chanson-humaniste-en-finale-4557332|title=RECAP - Destination Eurovision (France 2) : un ancien de The Voice et une chanson "humaniste" en finale|date=21 January 2018|website=www.programme-television.org}}{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/europe/refugee-crisis-latest-migrants-mediterranean-libya-boat-crossing-woman-give-birth-baby-mercy-rescue-a7642446.html|title=Woman gives birth to baby girl on refugee rescue boat as charities brace for spring surge|date=21 March 2017|accessdate=21 January 2018|last1=Dearden|first1=Lizzie|website=theindependent.co.uk}}{{cite web|url=http://www.infomigrants.net/fr/post/6854/mercy-le-bebe-migrant-qui-a-inspire-une-chanson-du-concours-de-l-eurovision|title=Mercy, the migrant baby who inspired a song for the Eurovision Song Contest|last1=Migrants|first1=Info|website=infomigrants.net|date=8 January 2018|accessdate=21 January 2018}}{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3Er-hawozGs|title=First reaction of Madame Monsieur after winning Destination Eurovision|date=28 January 2018|publisher=[[YouTube]]}} It is a play with words using the French word "merci" meaning "thanks" but also "mercy" like the English word and first name. ==Eurovision Song Contest== {{Main|France in the Eurovision Song Contest 2018}} On 1 January 2018, Madame Monsieur were confirmed as one of the 18 participants in ''Destination Eurovision'' with the song "Mercy".{{cite web|last1=Herbert|first1=Emily|title=France: Malo Confirmed as First Act For Destination Eurovision|url=https://eurovoix.com/2017/12/29/france-malo-confirmed-destination-eurovision/|website=Eurovoix.com|publisher=Eurovoix|date=29 December 2017|accessdate=30 December 2017}}{{cite web|last=Adams|first=William Lee|title=DESTINATION EUROVISION: WILL JUNE THE GIRL BE FRANCE’S SINGER IN MAY?|url=http://wiwibloggs.com/2017/12/30/destination-eurovision-will-june-the-girl-be-frances-singer-in-may/206046/|website=Wiwibloggs.com|publisher=Wiwibloggs|date=30 December 2017|accessdate=30 December 2017}}{{cite web|last=Weaver|first=Jessica|title=France: Last 9 Destination Eurovision 2018 acts unveiled|url=http://esctoday.com/155633/france-last-9-destination-eurovision-2018-acts-unveiled/|website=Esctoday.com|publisher=Esctoday|date=7 January 2018|accessdate=7 January 2018}} They advanced from the second semi-final on 20 January, after placing first with the international jury and tying for first with the Francophone jury.{{cite web|url=http://esctoday.com/156723/france-results-second-semi-final-destination-eurovision-2018/|title=France: Results of the second semi-final of Destination Eurovision 2018|date=20 January 2018|publisher=ESCToday|last=Senkishev|first=Georgi}}{{cite web|url=https://eurovoix.com/2018/01/21/france-destination-eurovision-viewing-figures-fall-400000/|title=France: Destination Eurovision Viewing Figures Fall By 400,000|last1=Granger|first1=Anthony|date=21 January 2018|website=eurovoix.com}}{{cite web|url=https://www.escdaily.com/last-four-qualifiers-join-malo-french-eurovision-final/|title=Madame Monsieur wins and joins Malo’ in French Destination Eurovision final|date=21 January 2018|last1=Tas|first1=Robin|website=escdaily.com}} They went on to compete in the final on 27 January, placing third with the international juries but winning a landslide share of the vote from the French public, amassing enough points to win the competition.{{cite web|last1=Savage|first1=William|title=Madame Monsieur win Destination Eurovision|url=https://www.eurovisionary.com/madame-monsieur-win-destination-eurovision/|website=EuroVisionary.com|publisher=EuroVisionary|date=27 January 2018|accessdate=27 January 2018}} As France is a member of the "[[Eurovision Song Contest#Big Four and Big Five|Big Five]]", the song automatically advanced to the final, held on 12 May 2018 in [[Lisbon]], Portugal.{{cite web|url=https://eurovision.tv/story/eurovision-2018-dates-and-host-city-confirmed|title=Lisbon revealed as Host City of the 2018 Eurovision Song Contest!|publisher=Eurovision.tv|accessdate=25 July 2017}}{{cite web |last=Jordan |first=Paul |date=12 January 2018 |url=https://eurovision.tv/story/all-aboard-for-eurovision-2018-semi-final-allocation-draw |title=All Aboard for the Semi-Final Allocation Draw |publisher=eurovision.tv |accessdate=12 January 2018}} At the Eurovision Grand Final, they won the Press [[Marcel Bezençon Award]], by being voted the best entry by the accredited media and press at the event. They finished 13th overall out of 43 participating countries. ==Commercial performance== The single started at number 8 on top singles sales in France.{{Cite news|url=http://www.snepmusique.com/tops-semaine/top-singles-telecharges/?ye=2018&we=4|title=Le Top de la semaine : Top Singles Téléchargés - SNEP|date=2014-01-25|work=SNEP|access-date=2018-02-06|language=fr-FR}} The next week, it peaked at number 3.{{Cite news|url=http://www.snepmusique.com/tops-semaine/top-singles-telecharges/?ye=2018&we=5|title=Le Top de la semaine : Top Singles Téléchargés - SNEP|date=2014-01-25|work=SNEP|access-date=2018-02-06|language=fr-FR}} After the Grand Final, the song rose to number 2.{{Cite web|url=http://www.chartsinfrance.net/charts/singles.php|title=Meilleures ventes de Singles et Titres en France (Top Singles)|website=www.chartsinfrance.net|access-date=2018-05-18}} ==Track listing== {{Track listing | headline = Digital download{{cite web|url=https://itunes.apple.com/fr/album/mercy-single/1331536750|title=Mercy - Single|publisher=iTunes|accessdate=28 January 2018}} | title1 = Mercy | length1 = 3:58 }} ==Charts== {| class="wikitable sortable plainrowheaders" style="text-align:center" |- ! scope="col"| Chart (2018) ! scope="col"| Peak

{{Infobox book | <!-- See Wikipedia:WikiProject_Novels or Wikipedia:WikiProject_Books --> | name = Out of Ireland | title_orig = | translator = | image = Cover_of_Out_of_Ireland_(novel).jpeg | caption = | author = [[Christopher Koch]] | illustrator = | cover_artist = | country = [[Australia]] | language = [[English language|English]] | series = | genre = [[Historical Fiction]] | publisher = [[Random House|Random House]] | publisher2 = | release_date = 1999 | media_type = Print ([[Hardcover|Hardback]] & [[Paperback]]) | pages = 720 | isbn = 978-0099286974 | oclc= | preceded_by = | followed_by = }} '''''Out of Ireland''''' is a 1999 novel by [[Christopher Koch]] which tells the story of Irish 'gentleman-convict' Robert Devereux and his transportation to Van Diemen's Land ([[Tasmania]]). Koch observed that ''Out of Ireland'' was an exploration of his "interest in the idea that the past resonates off the future."<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.smh.com.au/entertainment/books/a-life-full-of-achievements-20121012-27gc0.html | title=A life full of achievements | work=Sydney Morning Hearld | date=October 13, 2012 | accessdate=May 21, 2018 | author= Wyndham, Susan}}</ref> The novel is considered uniquely Tasmanian because of the way it deals with convict ancestry <ref>{{cite journal |first=Chad |last=Habel |title=Christopher Koch, Out of Ireland: no more 'Hiding the Stain'|journal=Australian Literary Studies in the 21st Century |volume= |issue= |year=2000 |pages=128-134 [p. 129] }}</ref> and emphasies the island's geographic isolation.<ref>{{cite journal |first=Paul |last=Genoi |title=Girt by Sea: islands in the novels of Thea Astley and Christopher Koch |journal=Australian Literary Studies in the 21st Century |volume= |issue= |year=2000 |pages=121-127 [p. 125] }}</ref>
==Plot== The novel starts with Devereux, an Irish revolutionary, aboard a convict prison hulk in Bermuda. It then follows his transportation to Van Diemen's Land, his release and subsequent adventures on the island.
==Reception== ''Out of Ireland'' was well received, winning the [[Colin Roderick Award]] in 1999 and the [[Victorian Premier's Prize for Fiction]] in 2000.

<!-- Rath Yatra Nabha is a festival of nabha city celebrated at the [[Saty Narayan Ji Mandir, Nabha]] celebrated as same celebrated at [[Puri]] [[Ratha Yatra]] ! --> <!-- This page is monitored regularly for nonsense and vandalism. People who vandalize articles about religious festival will be blocked from editing. If you would like to experiment with Wikipedia, please copy the following address into your browser's address bar: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Sandbox It will take you to a page where new users can try out the editing features! --> {{EngvarB|date=November 2015}} {{Use dmy dates|date=November 2015}} {{Infobox Rathayatra | name = Ratha Yatra of Nabha | type = Hindu | longtype = Religious | image = Ratha Yatra, Nabha.jpg | image_size = | alt = | caption = Nabha Rathayatra, 2015 | founded = 25 September 2014 | founded_by = Committee [[Mandir Thakur Shri Saty Narayan Ji]] | abolished = | abolished_by = [[ISKCON]] | place = [[Nabha]], [[Punjab, India|Punjab]], [[India]] | observedby = [[Hindu]]s | date = | date2014 = 25 August | date2015 = 12 September | organizer = Committee [[Mandir Thakur Shri Saty Narayan Ji]] | ratha_height = | ratha_base = | ratha_wheels = | ratha_style = | ratha_architect= | ratha_patron = | footnotes = | relatedto = }} '''Ratha Yatra''' ([[Oriya Language|Oriya]]: ରଥଯାତ୍ରା or '''Ratha Jatra''' or '''Chariot Festival''') is a [[Hindu festival]] associated with the god [[Jagannath]] held at [[Mandir Thakur Shri Saty Narayan Ji]] in the [[Nabha]] City, state of [[Punjab, India|Punjab]], India. This annual festival is celebrated in the month of August or September. The festival commemorates Jagannath's annual visit to [[Nabha]] city.
As part of Ratha Yatra, the deities of Jagannath, [[Balabhadra]] and [[Subhadra]] are taken out in a procession to Devi Chowk. Then the deities or Ratha Yatra starts and the Parikrama of the Nabha city. The return journey of Puri Jagannath Ratha Jatra is known as Bahuda Jatra. [[File:Prabhu Hari Kishore Joshi Holdin Lord Jagannath.jpg|thumb|Prabhu Hari Kishore Joshi Holdin Lord Jagannath]]
Three richly decorated [[Ratha|chariots]], resembling temple structures, are pulled through the streets of Puri called Badadanda. This commemorates the annual journey of Lord Jagannath, Lord Balabhadra, and their sister Subhadra to their aunt's temple, the [[Gundicha Temple]] which is situated at a distance of 2 km from their temple. This is the only day when devotees who are not allowed in the temple premises, such as non-Hindus and foreigners, can get their glimpse of the deities. During the festival, devotees from all over the world go to Puri with an earnest desire to help pull the Lords' chariots with the help of other priests pulling the chariots with ropes. They consider this a pious deed and risk their lives in the huge crowd. The huge processions accompanying the chariots play devotional songs with drums, tambourines, trumpets etc. Children line the streets through which the chariot will pass and add to the mass chorus. The [[Temple car|Rath]]a carts themselves are some approximately {{convert|45|ft|m}} high and are pulled by the thousands of pilgrims who turn up for the event; the chariots are built anew each year only from a particular type of tree. Millions of devotees congregate at Puri for this annual event from all over the country and abroad. It is also broadcast live on many Indian, foreign television channels as well as many of the websites telecast jagannath ratha yatra live.<ref>[http://www.iskcontruth.com ISKCON TRUTH] Live broadcast Jagannatha Ratha Yatra festival throughout the day</ref>
==Description== [[File:Ratha Yatra 2.jpg|thumb|Ratha Yatra 2]] Ratha Jatra, the Festival of Chariot: Chariots of Shri Jagannath is celebrated every year at Nabha, the temple town in Punjab. The presiding deities of the Lord [[Jagannath]], Lord [[Balabhadra]] and Goddess [[Subhadra]], with the celestial wheel ([[Sudarshana Chakra]]) are taken out from the temple precincts in an elaborate ritual procession to their chariot. The huge, colourfully decorated chariot is drawn by multitude of devotees on the ''Devi Chowk'', the grand avenue and the main place of the Nabha City. After the ratha yatra deities return to their abode.
[[File:Nabha Ratha Yatra.jpg|thumb|Nabha Ratha Yatra]] [[File:Bhajan Mandli 2.jpg|thumb|Bhajan Mandli 2]] [[File:Jagannath Ratha Yaera Nabha.JPG|thumb|Jagannath Ratha Yaera Nabha]]
== The Chariot == [[File:Bhajan Mandli.jpg|thumb|Bhajan Mandli]] The chariot of Balarama, Subhadra and Jagannatha is newly constructed every year with wood of specified trees like phassi, dhausa, etc. They are customarily brought from the ex-princely state of Dasapalla by a specialist team of carpenters who have hereditary rights and privileges for the same. The logs are traditionally set afloat as rafts in the river Mahanadi. These are collected near Puri and then transported by road.
The chariot is decorated as per the unique scheme prescribed and followed for centuries stand on the Santoshi Mata Mandir, Duladdi Gate the Grand Avenue. Covered with bright canopies made of stripes of red cloth and combined with those of black, yellow and blue colors, the huge chariot is lined across the wide avenue in front of the majestic temple close to its eastern entrance.
Lord Jagannatha's chariot is called Nandighosa. It is decked with a cover made of red and yellow cloth. Lord Jagannatha is identified with Krushna, who is also known as Pitambara, the one attired in golden yellow robes and hence the distinguishing yellow stripes on the canopy of this chariot.
The chariot of Lord Balarama, called the Taladhwaja, is the one with the Palm Tree on its flag.
The chariot of Subhadra, known as Dwarpadalana, literally "trampler of pride,” This chariot is decked with a covering of red and black cloth – black being traditionally associated with Shakti and the Mother Goddess.
Around the chariot are nine Parsva devatas, painted wooden images representing different deities on the chariots' sides. Chariots is attached to four horses. These are of different colours – dark ones for Balarama, white ones for Jagannatha, and red ones for Subhadra. Each chariot has a charioteer called Sarathi. '''Descriptions of the Chariots'''
==Examples==
[[File:ISCON Rath Yatra, Kolkata 2015.jpg|thumb|ISCON Rath Yatra, Kolkata 2015 in [[Kolkata]].]]
* [[Ratha-Yatra (Puri)]], at Puri in the state of Odisha, India is the oldest, biggest and most visited Rath Yatra in the world.{{citation needed|date=March 2016}} It attracts a large crowd. * SUKINDA [[ODISHA]] Ratha Yatra is the second Oldest in the world. * Mahesh [[Serampur, West Bengal]] Ratha Yatra is the third largest in the world. * [[Dhamrai Jagannath Roth]], at Dhamrai in Bangladesh, the most famous Rath Yatra in Bangladesh * ISKON [[Dhaka]] Ratha Yatra is the second famous Rath Yatra in Bangladesh. * [[Rathayatra of Mahesh]] at Mahesh in West Bengal * [[ISKCON Seshadripuram Bangalore#Festivals|Bangalore Ratha Yatra]], Bangalore's largest Ratha Yatra * [[Rajbalhat]] Ratha Yatra, West Bengal, India. * People of [[Bastar district|Bastar region]] observe Ratha yatra during [[Dussehara]].<ref>{{cite web |url= http://articles.economictimes.indiatimes.com/2003-09-25/news/27514315_1_bastar-colours-temple |title=Dussehra in Bastar -- a riot of colours - Economic Times |first=Partha |last=S Banerjee|work=indiatimes.com |year=2008|quote=The Bastar royal family figures prominently in the script and the props include a huge chariot that is first built, then ritually 'stolen', and then again recovered and pulled ceremonially through the streets of Jagdalpur |accessdate=9 January 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url= http://news.oneindia.in/2008/10/09/tribals-celebrate-unique-dussehra-in-bastar-1223542981.html |title=Tribals celebrate unique Dussehra in Bastar - Oneindia News |first= |last= |work=news.oneindia.in |year=2008 |quote=The another attraction of this 'tribal Dusshra', is a double- decked Rath (Chariot) with eight wheels and weighing about 30 tonnes. |accessdate=9 January 2013}}</ref> * Radha Rani Rath Yatra, held at the [[Radha Madhav Dham#Festivals|Radha Madhav Dham]] temple near Austin, Texas, U.S.A. * Ratha Yatra is also celebrated in Canada.
